[[#Islands|list]]) |islands_category = Islands of the Great Lakes |cities =
Buffalo, New York Erie, Pennsylvania Toledo, Ohio Cleveland, Ohio
|reference =  }} 'Lake Erie' United States Geological Survey
Hydrological Unit Code: 04-12-02-00 (; ) is the fourth largest lake (by
surface area) of the five Great Lakes in North America, and the tenth largest
globally [http://www.factmonster.com/ipka/A0001777.html Large Lakes of the World].
Factmonster.com. or twelfth largest globally if measured in terms of
surface area. It is the southernmost, shallowest, and
smallest by volume of the Great Lakes [http://www.factmonster.com/ce6/us/A0817584.html Erie,
Lake] and therefore also has the shortest average water . It is bounded by
Ontario to the north, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New York to the south, and
Michigan to the west. The lake is named after the Erie tribe of Native Americans
who lived along its southern shore. The outflow from the
lake provides hydroelectric power to Canada and the U.S. as it spins huge
turbines at Niagara Falls. {{cite news |title= From Honeymoon
City to Hydro City |publisher= CBC Digital Archives |date= Aug. 25, 1957 |url=
http://archives.cbc.ca/science_technology/energy_production/topics/1750-11987/
|accessdate= 2011-01-26 }} The lake's environmental health has been an
ongoing concern for decades, with issues such as overfishing, pollution and more
recently algal blooms and eutrophication generating headlines.
